awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Onsite Production of Carbon Monoxide from Carbon Dioxide using Modified Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Electolyzers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in the development of new carbon dioxide utilization technology for the commercialization of onsite gas production. The impediment to electrochemical carbon dioxide utilization technology has been the lack of an electrolyzer design capable of high production rates and high energy efficiency. This project will yield a novel electrolyzer component to overcome these challenges and demonstrate that cost-effective carbon dioxide utilization is possible. This component can be integrated into existing electrolyzer designs, and will enable such hardware to convert carbon dioxide into specialty gases. The resulting solution will have higher safety and lower cost than conventional packaged gas. Long term, this technology could be scaled up to higher volume applications, and used as a means of converting industrial carbon dioxide emissions into useful chemicals and fuels, thereby transforming a waste product into a new revenue stream. This scalable technology could therefore be the basis for the creation of new economic value and advanced manufacturing jobs in the United States, while providing a profitable way for existing U.S. industries to reduce their emissions.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will build upon the promising feasibility results achieved in Phase I to increase the performance of a novel carbon dioxide electrochemical cell along key performance dimensions, in order to deliver a commercially-relevant, cost-competitive solution. A viable solution to derive specialty gases from a low-cost feedstock like carbon dioxide will need to have high performance on several dimensions: energy efficiency, high reaction rates, long lifetime, and low capital cost. It will also need to operate at a scale that is industrially relevant. In Phase II, the novel electrochemical component will be scaled up to commercial dimensions, and the performance of the component will be optimized to meet the performance requirements identified during customer interviews. The final component will form the basis for a commercial unit, capable of producing specialty gases from carbon dioxide at cost-competitive rates. It will lay the foundation for future scale-up to even larger membrane areas, which will enable industrial-scale applications of this carbon dioxide conversion technology. Carbon dioxide emissions could be converted into valuable products using this technology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II grant resulted in significant progress of our CO2 electrolysis technology towards industrial-scale, onsite recycling of carbon dioxide into valuable chemicals and fuels. In Phase I, we showed that our CO2  electrolyzer could achieve commercially relevant electrochemical performance; in Phase II, we built upon those learnings to develop high-performance electrolyzer stacks, culminating in the world's first 5 kW polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) CO2 electrolyzer. Additionally, we expanded our repertoire of chemical products to include ethylene, a chemical compound that forms the basis of most of the world's plastics. These outcomes demonstrate the viability and versatility of our CO2 electrolysis technology. 

The main goal of this project was to identify and overcome the technical barriers separating single-cell electrolyzers from multi-cell electrolyzer stacks. Single-cell electrolyzers represent an excellent model system for studying electrolysis, but are not industrially viable due to their limited production capabilities. Large, multi-cell electrolyzer stacks, on the other hand, can be cost-competitive with conventional chemical production pathways, provided that certain technoeconomic metrics are met. In order to reach those performance goals and subsequently translate that performance to multi-cell electrolyzer stacks, we extensively studied the relationship between fabrication parameters and electrolyzer characteristics. We then utilized this knowledge to redesign and optimize our manufacturing processes for electrolyzer performance, consistency, operational stability, and manufacturing speed. These advances have been leveraged to produce a 5 kW CO2 electrolyzer module as well as the world's first CO2-derived car parts and sunglasses. Other demonstrations of our technology are forthcoming.

Our technology platform can be directly integrated into existing chemical manufacturing schemes, allowing for the conversion of CO2 into specialty gases in a safe and cost-competitive manner compared to conventional packaged gas. At large volumes, this technology can be used to significantly reduce CO2 emissions and create new revenue streams utilizing CO2. Moreover, as our technology has no moving parts and only requires electricity, water and CO2 as inputs, it can be deployed in a range of environments, potentially creating jobs and chemical production capabilities in regions of the country that have historically gravitated towards other sectors. This technology platform could therefore become a driver of new economic value and advanced manufacturing jobs in the United States, all while significantly reducing the nation's carbon footprint.


Last Modified: 05/27/2022
Modified by: Sichao Ma
